title: Valued in Questions
teaser: Discovering that God's love is not conditional on our physical perfection or circumstances
theme: Discovering that questioning our worth is really questioning the gospel — and the gospel answers back

emphasis: the gospel I preached to you
on which you have taken your stand
modules.passage: Now, brothers and sisters, I want to remind you of the gospel I preached to you, which you received and on which you have taken your stand. By this gospel you are saved, if you hold firmly to the word I preached to you. Otherwise, you have believed in vain.
modules.fullPassage: Now, brothers and sisters, I want to remind you of the gospel I preached to you, which you received and on which you have taken your stand. By this gospel you are saved, if you hold firmly to the word I preached to you. Otherwise, you have believed in vain.

modules.rootMeaning: From 'eu' (good) and 'angelia' (message). In the ancient world, a euangelion was a proclamation of victory — a herald running from the battlefield to announce that the war was won. Paul uses it to describe the ultimate victory announcement: death is defeated, and you are valued beyond measure.
modules.usageNote: Paul uses euangelion over 60 times in his letters. It is not merely information to be learned but a reality to be received and stood upon — the foundation of identity and worth.

relatedWords.reference: One who proclaims the good news — an evangelist

modules.usage: The gospel is not merely information about God's love — it is the foundation on which our entire sense of worth and identity must stand.

modules.body:
Paul writes to the Corinthians not to introduce the gospel but to remind them of it. He knows how easily we forget the foundation when life's questions pile up. The gospel isn't a set of theological facts to memorize — it's the ground we stand on when everything else shifts beneath us.

When Nick Vujicic questioned his value as a child born without arms or legs, he was doing what every human does in seasons of pain: testing whether the gospel can hold the weight of real suffering. Paul's answer is unequivocal — hold firmly. Not because the gospel is fragile, but because our grip loosens when doubt presses in.

Our value doesn't come from what we can do with our hands or feet. It comes from what Christ has done with His. When doubt whispers that we're worthless, the gospel shouts that we're priceless.
modules.keyInsight: Questioning our worth is really questioning the gospel itself. And the gospel has already answered: you are worth the life of God's Son.

modules.heading: The Foundation Under the Questions

modules.body:
Nick Vujicic was born with tetra-amelia syndrome, a rare condition leaving him without arms or legs. As a child, he would stare at his reflection and ask, 'Am I valued by God?' The question haunted him through sleepless nights and tear-filled days. At age eight, he began contemplating suicide, convinced that his life had no purpose or worth.

Yet in those darkest moments, God was already preparing to reveal a value that transcended every human measurement. The boy who questioned whether God had made a mistake would grow to speak to millions, showing them a worth that no body or circumstance can define.
modules.connectionToTheme: Nick's childhood questions represent the universal human cry: Does God see me? Does my existence matter? The gospel answers with the cross.

modules.heading: The Boy Who Asked God Why

modules.body:
Nick's parents planted seeds of love, teachers watered with education, but only God could make Nick's purpose grow. In our questioning seasons, we often focus on human efforts — what we've done, what others have contributed, what we lack. But Paul reminds us in 1 Corinthians 3:6-7 that growth comes from God alone.

The questions that torment us about our value miss the point entirely: we don't grow ourselves into worthiness. God grows us into His purposes. Our value isn't in our ability to produce growth, but in being the soil where God chooses to work.
modules.historicalContext: In first-century Corinth, social worth was determined by rhetorical skill, wealth, and patron connections. Paul deliberately subverts this value system by grounding worth in the gospel rather than human achievement — a message as radical then as it is now.
modules.fascinatingFact: The word Paul uses for 'stand' (histemi) in verse 2 is the same word used for a soldier standing at his post. Our position in the gospel isn't passive — it's an active stance of trust, holding our ground when everything around us says to retreat.

modules.heading: God Grows What We Cannot

modules.ancientTruth: Paul urged the Corinthians to hold firmly to the gospel as the foundation of their salvation and identity — not their status, skill, or strength.
modules.modernApplication: We measure worth by followers, productivity, appearance, and ability. Nick Vujicic had none of these by human standards — yet God was building something extraordinary through him.
modules.connectionPoint: The same gospel that sustained Paul through shipwrecks and imprisonment sustained Nick through childhood despair. It sustains us through our own seasons of questioning.
modules.newTestamentEcho: Even as young Nick wrestled with questions about his value, God was already at work keeping him firm. 'God is faithful, who has called you into fellowship with his Son' (1 Corinthians 1:9).

modules.prompt: What circumstances in your life make you question your worth to God?
additionalQuestions: When doubt whispers that you're worthless, what gospel truth can you hold firmly to?
How has God shown His faithfulness to you even in seasons of questioning?
What would change if you believed that your value was settled at the cross, not determined by your circumstances?

modules.prayerText: Lord, I confess that I've let my circumstances define my worth instead of Your gospel. Help me hold firmly to the truth that I am valued — not because of what I can do, but because of what Christ has done. When questions rise, anchor me in Your faithfulness. Amen.

modules.commitment: I will write down one truth about God's love that remains constant regardless of my circumstances, and I will return to it each time doubt questions my worth.
leavingAtCross: The belief that my worth depends on my abilities or circumstances
The habit of letting doubt define my identity
The fear that God made a mistake when He made me
receivingFromCross: The truth that my value was settled at Calvary
The freedom to question without losing my standing
The assurance that God's faithfulness does not depend on my feelings

forReflection: How does understanding the gospel change your perspective on personal worth?

modules.name: Nick Vujicic
modules.title: The Boy Who Asked God Why
modules.description: Born in 1982 in Melbourne, Australia, with tetra-amelia syndrome — the complete absence of all four limbs. As a child, Nick questioned whether God had made a mistake. His journey from despair to purpose would eventually touch millions across 60 countries through his Life Without Limbs ministry.
modules.keyQuote: If God can use a man without arms and legs to be His hands and feet, then He will certainly use any willing heart.
modules.lessonForUs: Our questions about our worth are not signs of weak faith — they are invitations for God to reveal a deeper truth about our value than we could have discovered in comfort.
modules.heading: Nick Vujicic — The Boy Who Asked God Why
